At a meeting of the Dramatic
Club last Monday the resignation
of Fred Lipps, as property man,
was accepted, and George Hardy
was appointed to take his place.
Several committees were selected
by President Engel. Henry West
is in charge of publicity and he
plans in the near future to canvass the various high schools,
"prep." schools and colleges in the
city.
Tickets will be sent to all alumni with a personal letter from Mr.
W. B. Swindell, Jr., who is coaching the play and who is also a
Prominent member of the alumni
association, Mariano Badillo and
his staff of artists, who painted
the posters for the senior prom,
are busy painting advertisements
on burlap and cardboard. It is
planned to flood the city with
these about two weeks before the
production.
Peirce Brawner is in charge of
the costume committee. Jones has
been awarded the contract for the
costumes and he has already taken
the measurements of some of the
cast. He promises to make the
costumes better and more pretentious than any the Dramatic Club
has ever had.
The job of getting patronesses
was given to Bosley Hiss. This
year the Dramatic Club wishes to
get a long list of patronesses who
will not only let their names be
used, but who will be there themselves and will advertise the club
to their friends.
President Engel has asked each
fraternity to send out two men to
make up the necessary auxiliaries.
There are about fifty "supes" necessary for the show, but these will
be "cut" and "doubled", so that
the twenty from the ten fraternities will be enough to carry it
through.
The tickets have been on sale
now for nearly a week. The sale
so far has been very good, and it
looks, from all indications, as
though the S. R. 0. sign will be
hung out on the twenty-seventh
of March.
With only four weeks before
the "first night," Badillo and Hardy are working diligently with
their staff of assistants. If Badillo's creations this year are
exactly like the models he has
made, they will, if possible, be
better and more elaborate than
last year.
The cast, under the tutelage of
Mr. Swindell, has been rehearsing
five times weekly and is rapidly
becoming familiar with the lines.
Several changes in the cast have
been made since the original announcement. Moore is now playing the part of Louis XI., King
of France, and Kirkley is taking
the role of Olivier le Dain. Eli
Frank has been changed to the
part of Guy Tabaric. Tryouts are
being held for the part of Thibaut d'Aussigny.

everything is in readiness to make the drive a big success, except
that a sufficient number of leaders have not yet volunteered as captains of non-fraternity teams. There are plenty of men on the campus with sufficient ability to lead a team in the competition, but
they have yet to come forward. They are very badly needed and

THE PROPOSED FRATERNITY RUSHING SEASON
The proposed fraternity rushing season agreement, which is now
before the respective chapters, would go a long way toward preventing unnecessary friction between the various groups next year.
By providing a long period in which the fraternities and new men
can look each other over it would prevent many regrets on both
sides, and by allowing the open discussion of fraternities, it would
abolish much hitherto unavoidable suspicion. The section which allows a certain time for each fraternity's party would do away with
much hard feeling, while by preventing the cutting of morning
classes and forbidding initiation until after the mid-year examinations, the scholarship of the entering class would be much improved.
The late date of opening is welcomed by the athletic authorities, and
the clause limiting the number of dates any fraternity may have with
one man is admittedly fair. Incidentally, the clause requiring from
each fraternity a bond of $100.00 against infractions would do much
to prevent any violations.

Following the unfortunate error
of the starter in the 1,000-yard
Varsity Club Special race of last

be taken to rectify the mistake.

first three runners. The men to
receive these trophies will be Crawford, of Lafayette; Shields, of
Penn State, and Hays, of Pittsburgh.
A gold watch, the most valuable

THE PROPOSED FRATERNITY RUSHING SEASON
The proposed fraternity rushing season agreement, which is now
before the respective chapters, would go a long way toward preventing unnecessary friction between the various groups next year.
By providing a long period in which the fraternities and new men
can look each other over it would prevent many regrets on both
sides, and by allowing the open discussion of fraternities, it would
abolish much hitherto unavoidable suspicion. The section which allows a certain time for each fraternity's party would do away with
much hard feeling, while by preventing the cutting of morning
classes and forbidding initiation until after the mid-year examinations, the scholarship of the entering class would be much improved.
The late date of opening is welcomed by the athletic authorities, and
the clause limiting the number of dates any fraternity may have with
one man is admittedly fair. Incidentally, the clause requiring from
each fraternity a bond of $100.00 against infractions would do much
to prevent any violations.
